[u]Pros:[/u]
+ freedom of building
+ very fun early game
+ different win criteria
[u]Cons:[/u]
- more like a business sim than school management
- repetitive gameplay loop fails to entertain after a while
- clunky UI
- devs abandoned the game (no more patches, QoL, bugfixes)

This is the game I have been dreaming of. Something in-depth, quirky, managerial, customizable, intuitive. Honestly, the only thing holding this back from being as worldwide popular as the Sims/My Sims or Rollercoaster Tycoon is the original marketing and bias against non-English games. I felt the same bias when I wanted to explore the workshop but most the items were in Chinese. But that should not stop ANYONE from getting this game. I genuinely love every bit of this from the mix-maxing, to the quirky storylines and caring for the community, to just building some cool school. I am actively working towards a save that is entirely focused on making an architecture trade school essentially, but I haven't discovered eveything there is to offer yet. Again, highly recommend. Truly wish this was more popular than it is.

Let‚Äôs School is basically what happens when you think running a school is easy‚Ä¶ and then reality drop-kicks you. The game looks cute, but don‚Äôt be fooled‚Äîyour students will test your patience, your teachers will beg for training, and your campus will constantly demand upgrades like it‚Äôs never enough.

     Still, it‚Äôs ridiculously fun. Building classrooms, decorating the campus, and watching your little troublemakers grow is surprisingly satisfying. Every student has their own personality, which means you‚Äôll deal with everything from lazy sleepers to overachievers who panic over a B+.

      However, it feels like the developers have abandoned this poor child of theirs to chase other projects. It‚Äôs a shame, because the game has a ton of potential. I really hope one day it gets some proper DLC to bring the experience to the next level.

      Yeah, some systems get repetitive, and the UI sometimes feels like it‚Äôs judging you. But overall, Let‚Äôs School is a chaotic, charming management sim that turns school stress into pure entertainment.

      If you‚Äôve ever wanted to run a school without actually crying in real life‚Äîthis is your chance.

      I love this game!

Despite the devs having ceased all work on this game, it still remains very cozy and fun as the day I first bought it. I love the community and work shop mods as they help keep the game fresh while still remaining faithful to the designs.
10/10 experience!

[i]Let's School is a surprisingly deep school management sim. At first glance, it looks like a cute, chill game, but nah, it throws you right into some super deep and addictive management stuff. You're the principal, designing the whole campus, hiring teachers, setting up the curriculum, and straight-up dealing with delinquent kids. It covers the whole school life cycle, letting you get that director-strategist feeling. It's a blast overall.[/i]

[h2]The Vibe Check & Modder MVPs[/h2]

Honestly, the game gives off some pretty solid vibes, offering a fun loop of growth and upgrades. But, you hit the nail on the head: the atmosphere is kinda all over the place.

The supposed "Japanese atmosphere" in the vanilla game is, like, barely there. Yeah, the general art style leans East, but it totally lacks the detail and authenticity needed for real immersion. This is where we gotta give a huge shoutout to the modders - they are the real MVPs. Their custom furniture models and Japanese interior packs are what actually level up the immersion, turning a good sim into something truly stylish and legit.

[h2]The Vibe Check & Modder MVPs[/h2]

My experience with visual fatigue is a critical warning for anyone thinking about buying this. You mentioned that after just 1‚Äì2 hours, your eyes get straight-up bloodshot, like Bugs Bunny after an all-nighter.

This strongly suggests the game has way too bright and high-contrast graphics that you can‚Äôt properly fix with the standard in-game settings. When you have to rock blue-light glasses or mess with your monitor's settings just to tone down the contrast, that‚Äôs a major UI/color palette fail. The devs seriously need to look into this, because visual discomfort is a huge buzzkill and totally ruins the game‚Äôs longevity. :/

[h2]Final Take[/h2]

Let's School is an engaging, deep sim that gives you that sweet satisfaction of building a successful, functioning academic machine. If you gotta be cool with the fact that you need the modding community to get that perfect Japanese aesthetic, and you're willing to take precautions for your eyes against the harsh contrast, then it's a solid way to kill some time. It's the kind of game that leaves you feeling good, despite a few annoying technical snags in the visuals department.
If you like tycoon games, this is a really well made tycoon game, genuinely had a ton of fun playing it.

Don't let the cartoonish art style fool you; underneath what might look like a children's game is a surprisingly complicated management game with a lot of moving parts. You set up departments, revise class schedules, plan fieldtrips, research, train, patrol. The children learn according to their abilities, their moods, their schedules, and their teachers, and must pass exams at the end of each semester. They bring contraband and bully each other and have friendships or illness and all of this affects their studies. You build and expand and decorate (although it needs a lot more decor!) and give inspiring or scolding speeches. And while it might sound like a chore, it's not‚Äîautomated defaults and thoughtful design choices make everything convenient and gamefied. There's so much to do, it's easy to get sucked in once you've got the hang of it. It might be overwhelming at first, however.

If you like sim management games like Planet Zoo or Two Point Museum and would like similar but in a very different flavor, I highly recommend Let's School. It's not quite as polished, but the scope of interlocking management features is impressive, while remaining cute and fun.

If you like management games, this one definitely satisfies the itch. I put 26 hours into the game over a weekend. Learning curve pretty easy. I had one "year" where I expanded too fast but was still able to make up for it. I love how easy they make rearranging/placing rooms.

ive played many school simulators but this one is probably my favourite. i have 100 hours but i am still learning things about this game all the time. i like the rival school system (you can trade with them, get additional uniforms for students or really good teachers), the clubs (you train your different clubs to try and become state champs) and even the janky design of it all. is it perfect? no not at all but i still get a smile when i take a photo with each graduating class :) 

would defs pick this up on sale!

Superb game, lots and lots of depth to this game and I've spent a few fun days with it, but it has some really stupid issue that should have been fixed before the [b]devs abandoned it[/b].

This game is riddle with little annoying bugs that should have been fixed. It has a lot of information screens that tell you very little and lacks information screens that you'll be wishing you had.

It will tell you a room has an error, but that is it. No guidance on what the error is, so you have to guess and hope you work it out.

Then there is the most annoying issue of all, that should have never existed. The game is about designing and running a school, it has objects, fences and bushes. Well the devs forgot to enable any collision on the fences and bushes rendering the functionally useless. The characters walk through fences and bushes as if they don't exist.

It's a fun game and you'll enjoy the depth, but if you're wanting to build a great looking school, good luck making the character not randomly walk around where you don't want them because the fences do nothing.

üè´ Incredibly enjoyable, fun, and cute. Great variety in building and environment design. Lots and LOTS of nice little touches (from visuals to features). Clear and convenient management that doesn't require time-consuming guides or wikis. A true gem for fans of the above. Despite minor flaws and tech. bugs (which aren't game-breaking but require some polishing; there are only two devs credited), the offered content will keep you entertained for dozens of hours (and that's just ONE session!) Seasonal changes, room temperatures, cleaning radius, lunch calorie counts, rival schools, student uniform selection, and random staff generation (appearance, stats, specialty). There are many hilarious, important, and interesting moments / events related to the director's life in a casual presentation of economics & education. Great potential for modding and DLC's. Too engaging! Definitely recommended, keep up the good work!

Let' School is an adorable school building simulator:

Pros:
-The most important part: building and organizing your school is fun and easy to use.
-The lesson planning portion is a fun extra layer.
-3D models aren't my favs, but I like the general aesthetic of the game and character art.
Cons:
-Only two choices of afterschool clubs, pop music or basketball. Would love to have more options, especially as your student base expands.
-Students will occasionally return as teachers, but otherwise once they graduate they disappear into the ether. Would love to have some sort of internal record, but it might be too much of a memory burden.
-Building ACs is a pain in the butt since the external hvac doesn't count as part of the room.
-Interactions with other schools can feel kind of basic.

Overall: A very cute pretty fleshed out school simulator game, that really accomplishes what I look for in one of these games. So much room to obsess over, but also the option to keep it simple. Would love to see updates to build off the very good base that's already there.

Rating: 9/10

This game scratched an itch in my brain of all the tycoon games I played growing up, combined with a style that is reminiscent of Two Point Hospital/Campus games. It‚Äôs challenging and takes some skills to navigate but all the more rewarding when you succeed and get things right <3

Setting out to make the art school of my dreams once all my artsy students stop bullying everyone and flunking out

This is like a sweet snack version of a sim building game. Everything is very cute, the sounds and colors are refreshing, the mechanics are mostly pretty easily understood and there are just enough annoying bits to make it engaging and rewarding.

Designing my first school has been really chill since you can actually just pick up entire rooms and shift them around like legos. You can overrun your with cats by adopting every single feline that is abandoned outside the school gates. I am unsure if all the teachers are chubby bc I made my character chubby or if I need to consider the caloric value of all the stuff sold on campus. There is a song building feature for the music club. At the end of the research tree there is an option for a helipad. This feels cute but it scales up complexity well and is very much a game to vibe with for hours and hours to come. 

Functionally I have only encountered an occasional bug where I can't click the reprimand button on students, but everything is generally snappy and aesthetically pleasing and it includes some (somewhat limiting) features to automate enrollment and curriculum planning, but I can only completely recommend this game if the idea is interesting to you.

Btw, while it is a "school" sim, it is Japanese school system-style, so it might not be your cup of tea.

Let‚Äôs School is basically what happens when you think running a school is easy‚Ä¶ and then reality drop-kicks you. The game looks cute, but don‚Äôt be fooled‚Äîyour students will test your patience, your teachers will beg for training, and your campus will constantly demand upgrades like it‚Äôs never enough.

     Still, it‚Äôs ridiculously fun. Building classrooms, decorating the campus, and watching your little troublemakers grow is surprisingly satisfying. Every student has their own personality, which means you‚Äôll deal with everything from lazy sleepers to overachievers who panic over a B+.

      However, it feels like the developers have abandoned this poor child of theirs to chase other projects. It‚Äôs a shame, because the game has a ton of potential. I really hope one day it gets some proper DLC to bring the experience to the next level.

      Yeah, some systems get repetitive, and the UI sometimes feels like it‚Äôs judging you. But overall, Let‚Äôs School is a chaotic, charming management sim that turns school stress into pure entertainment.

      If you‚Äôve ever wanted to run a school without actually crying in real life‚Äîthis is your chance.

      I love this game!

At first the controls were a little hard to get used to (as with most building games), but they became intuitive and easy to use!  I 100% recommend the game, but the items listed below are suggestions for better QOL.

Having almost "completed" my first play through, here are a few suggestions for the devs:

Wonders do not reduce volume based on your selection in the menu.  Headphone users beware.

Auto-expedition and auto-training would be AMAZING.

Building can be a little wonky.  Sometimes you have to escape out of everything and then click on the room, and go back into build mode.  You can only move objects in certain build modes.  I've found it frustrating that I'll make a room, then for some reason can't save the changes due to one thing making the room "unusable", so I have to back out and it removes everything I've done.

While in "build mode", anything that you build then remove in that session should be fully refunded.  This really only affects you in the early to mid game, but it is a mild frustration because sometimes you would have to exit build mode to get all your money back, then start again.

In mid-game, deliquency is a little annoying to deal with.  It would be great if there was an "auto-deliquency" option where you can set the left click setting to always "reprimand" or "punish".  Better yet, it'd be nice if the security cameras would automatically send any idle teachers/guards to the room to take care of the issue for you.

Security scanners should just generate a notification and deposit the items into your inventory.  That would be a small QOL update because having to go around to each classroom and then click confirm on a pop-up is a little tedious.

Pop-ups for students that are eligible to be expelled if clicked should ideally take you to that student so you have the opportunity to expel them.  I have yet to expel a student, but it would be a nice QOL update.

End of year speeches would be great if you could create a speech template, and you can select it without needing to go through it every time.

Upgrading desks in classrooms (from shabby to the desks that take up more space) could potentially be a little quicker/easier... if you are putting in a 4-seater desk, it could auto-delete the other desks that are in that area instead of you needing to delete the desks.

There's probably some more things, but honestly this is a great game and even though there are some minor things, I would 100% recommend getting the game.

If there's anything in here that I've somehow missed how to do in the gameplay please let me know, I would greatly appreciate it.

[i]Let's School is a surprisingly deep school management sim. At first glance, it looks like a cute, chill game, but nah, it throws you right into some super deep and addictive management stuff. You're the principal, designing the whole campus, hiring teachers, setting up the curriculum, and straight-up dealing with delinquent kids. It covers the whole school life cycle, letting you get that director-strategist feeling. It's a blast overall.[/i]

[h2]The Vibe Check & Modder MVPs[/h2]

Honestly, the game gives off some pretty solid vibes, offering a fun loop of growth and upgrades. But, you hit the nail on the head: the atmosphere is kinda all over the place.

The supposed "Japanese atmosphere" in the vanilla game is, like, barely there. Yeah, the general art style leans East, but it totally lacks the detail and authenticity needed for real immersion. This is where we gotta give a huge shoutout to the modders - they are the real MVPs. Their custom furniture models and Japanese interior packs are what actually level up the immersion, turning a good sim into something truly stylish and legit.

[h2]The Vibe Check & Modder MVPs[/h2]

My experience with visual fatigue is a critical warning for anyone thinking about buying this. You mentioned that after just 1‚Äì2 hours, your eyes get straight-up bloodshot, like Bugs Bunny after an all-nighter.

This strongly suggests the game has way too bright and high-contrast graphics that you can‚Äôt properly fix with the standard in-game settings. When you have to rock blue-light glasses or mess with your monitor's settings just to tone down the contrast, that‚Äôs a major UI/color palette fail. The devs seriously need to look into this, because visual discomfort is a huge buzzkill and totally ruins the game‚Äôs longevity. :/

[h2]Final Take[/h2]

Let's School is an engaging, deep sim that gives you that sweet satisfaction of building a successful, functioning academic machine. If you gotta be cool with the fact that you need the modding community to get that perfect Japanese aesthetic, and you're willing to take precautions for your eyes against the harsh contrast, then it's a solid way to kill some time. It's the kind of game that leaves you feeling good, despite a few annoying technical snags in the visuals department.

Don't let the cartoonish art style fool you; underneath what might look like a children's game is a surprisingly complicated management game with a lot of moving parts. You set up departments, revise class schedules, plan fieldtrips, research, train, patrol. The children learn according to their abilities, their moods, their schedules, and their teachers, and must pass exams at the end of each semester. They bring contraband and bully each other and have friendships or illness and all of this affects their studies. You build and expand and decorate (although it needs a lot more decor!) and give inspiring or scolding speeches. And while it might sound like a chore, it's not‚Äîautomated defaults and thoughtful design choices make everything convenient and gamefied. There's so much to do, it's easy to get sucked in once you've got the hang of it. It might be overwhelming at first, however.

If you like sim management games like Planet Zoo or Two Point Museum and would like similar but in a very different flavor, I highly recommend Let's School. It's not quite as polished, but the scope of interlocking management features is impressive, while remaining cute and fun.

If you like management games, this one definitely satisfies the itch. I put 26 hours into the game over a weekend. Learning curve pretty easy. I had one "year" where I expanded too fast but was still able to make up for it. I love how easy they make rearranging/placing rooms.

Superb game, lots and lots of depth to this game and I've spent a few fun days with it, but it has some really stupid issue that should have been fixed before the [b]devs abandoned it[/b].

This game is riddle with little annoying bugs that should have been fixed. It has a lot of information screens that tell you very little and lacks information screens that you'll be wishing you had.

It will tell you a room has an error, but that is it. No guidance on what the error is, so you have to guess and hope you work it out.

Then there is the most annoying issue of all, that should have never existed. The game is about designing and running a school, it has objects, fences and bushes. Well the devs forgot to enable any collision on the fences and bushes rendering the functionally useless. The characters walk through fences and bushes as if they don't exist.

It's a fun game and you'll enjoy the depth, but if you're wanting to build a great looking school, good luck making the character not randomly walk around where you don't want them because the fences do nothing.

üè´ Incredibly enjoyable, fun, and cute. Great variety in building and environment design. Lots and LOTS of nice little touches (from visuals to features). Clear and convenient management that doesn't require time-consuming guides or wikis. A true gem for fans of the above. Despite minor flaws and tech. bugs (which aren't game-breaking but require some polishing; there are only two devs credited), the offered content will keep you entertained for dozens of hours (and that's just ONE session!) Seasonal changes, room temperatures, cleaning radius, lunch calorie counts, rival schools, student uniform selection, and random staff generation (appearance, stats, specialty). There are many hilarious, important, and interesting moments / events related to the director's life in a casual presentation of economics & education. Great potential for modding and DLC's. Too engaging! Definitely recommended, keep up the good work!

Let' School is an adorable school building simulator:

Pros:
-The most important part: building and organizing your school is fun and easy to use.
-The lesson planning portion is a fun extra layer.
-3D models aren't my favs, but I like the general aesthetic of the game and character art.
Cons:
-Only two choices of afterschool clubs, pop music or basketball. Would love to have more options, especially as your student base expands.
-Students will occasionally return as teachers, but otherwise once they graduate they disappear into the ether. Would love to have some sort of internal record, but it might be too much of a memory burden.
-Building ACs is a pain in the butt since the external hvac doesn't count as part of the room.
-Interactions with other schools can feel kind of basic.

Overall: A very cute pretty fleshed out school simulator game, that really accomplishes what I look for in one of these games. So much room to obsess over, but also the option to keep it simple. Would love to see updates to build off the very good base that's already there.

Rating: 9/10

This game scratched an itch in my brain of all the tycoon games I played growing up, combined with a style that is reminiscent of Two Point Hospital/Campus games. It‚Äôs challenging and takes some skills to navigate but all the more rewarding when you succeed and get things right <3

This is like a sweet snack version of a sim building game. Everything is very cute, the sounds and colors are refreshing, the mechanics are mostly pretty easily understood and there are just enough annoying bits to make it engaging and rewarding.

Designing my first school has been really chill since you can actually just pick up entire rooms and shift them around like legos. You can overrun your with cats by adopting every single feline that is abandoned outside the school gates. I am unsure if all the teachers are chubby bc I made my character chubby or if I need to consider the caloric value of all the stuff sold on campus. There is a song building feature for the music club. At the end of the research tree there is an option for a helipad. This feels cute but it scales up complexity well and is very much a game to vibe with for hours and hours to come. 

Functionally I have only encountered an occasional bug where I can't click the reprimand button on students, but everything is generally snappy and aesthetically pleasing and it includes some (somewhat limiting) features to automate enrollment and curriculum planning, but I can only completely recommend this game if the idea is interesting to you.

Btw, while it is a "school" sim, it is Japanese school system-style, so it might not be your cup of tea.

Let‚Äôs School is basically what happens when you think running a school is easy‚Ä¶ and then reality drop-kicks you. The game looks cute, but don‚Äôt be fooled‚Äîyour students will test your patience, your teachers will beg for training, and your campus will constantly demand upgrades like it‚Äôs never enough.

     Still, it‚Äôs ridiculously fun. Building classrooms, decorating the campus, and watching your little troublemakers grow is surprisingly satisfying. Every student has their own personality, which means you‚Äôll deal with everything from lazy sleepers to overachievers who panic over a B+.

      However, it feels like the developers have abandoned this poor child of theirs to chase other projects. It‚Äôs a shame, because the game has a ton of potential. I really hope one day it gets some proper DLC to bring the experience to the next level.

      Yeah, some systems get repetitive, and the UI sometimes feels like it‚Äôs judging you. But overall, Let‚Äôs School is a chaotic, charming management sim that turns school stress into pure entertainment.

      If you‚Äôve ever wanted to run a school without actually crying in real life‚Äîthis is your chance.

      I love this game!

Despite the devs having ceased all work on this game, it still remains very cozy and fun as the day I first bought it. I love the community and work shop mods as they help keep the game fresh while still remaining faithful to the designs.
10/10 experience!

negative.review:
So sad, this game could be really nice. It feels like a neat managemen simulation of a school. There is a big level of complexity, construction and management.
However, the UI/UX is abyssimal. Most of the time you have no idea what influences what. Aside from that there are some terrible design choices. E.g. why is a class always linked to a room? I for one build in advance so I create a new classroom for the upcoming school year. However, that creates a new class that is shown as error (since there are no teachers or students in it). The next year then it gets promoted to grade 2 where as it was only meant for grade one by then.
This is just one of so many examples which makes the game cluttered and hard to understand. There are many values shown where you just don't have any idea where they are coming from nor what they do. Its basically learning by doing.

The UI is not very intuitive, and the tutorial doesn't do a very good job of explaining things. After trying three times (twice in career, once in sandbox) the gameplay feels sluggish and repetitive. Maybe after you get past the first 2-3 weeks of classes it improves, but overall it just wasn't fun. Wish I hadn't played for more than two hours since my refund request was rejected based on playtime. Oh well, at least it was on sale so it wasn't a total waste of money.

I received this as a gift and I have absolutely no idea how this game has this positive reviews.

Granted, I've only gotten 16 minutes into this game, but there's a reason for that:

- Both the English and German translations are clearly either unreviewed AI/machine translation or created without providing the translators with any context. The German version of "let's give back to the local community" is translated literally, ending up as the equivalent of "let us return items backwards toward the localised group". It's incomprehensible in most cases. UI translations are messed up and don't fit the context in which they are used. For example, the average employee satisfaction UI element is awkwardly called "Happiness of the employee". It's AI or cheap outsourcing nonsense.

- Text bleeds out of their respective areas and boxes constantly and UI clips into each other. The text of the "Save and quit" button in German ("Speichern und beenden") is double the length of the button that's supposed to hold it, cutting off on both sides.

- I think the game should disclose a little more clearly that it's specifically simulating a certain kind of Japanese schools. The entire structure of the game and its school system is based on Japan, which was a disappointment for me as I was looking for a relatively relatable school management tycoon game, and the idea of sex-segregation, school uniforms and such are alien and offputting to me.

- The art style and writing are so far generic and uninspired, it's very much the kind of dialogue you'd get in a free mobile game trying to make you buy ingame currency 'to speed up construction' or whatnot. You get utterly generic characters like "Brick the Construction Assistant" telling you how to use the demolition feature, while you can practically smell that "Buy 5 gems now or watch an ad to instantly complete demolition!" that thankfully never comes; it feels like no love or passion went into the game at all.

Either way, this looks and feels very, very much like a cheap, barely functional, janky mobile game rather than a fully-fledged PC management tycoon.

Worst of all (as mentioned) the translations ‚Äì for German especially ‚Äì are genuinely incomprehensible. Looking into the credits, they were made by some random Chinese company, with no actual translators or localisation QA folks credited by name. It's probably just AI. That's honestly the worst part. It's practically unplayable in German.
this had so much potential but there are so many bugs that developers refuse to fix, there hasn't been an update in over a year

I actually really like the game. Especially designing the school is a delight.

However, one aspect I feel is completely unnecessary and drags the game: Research.

You NEED to research because you will be required to teach advanced subjects that you need to research, and not just that, but to unlock things such as heating, cleaning, student club, etc. It's a drag on your economy as research requires you to hire staff dedicated to it. Also if you are behind, it basically bombs your game because you can't teach the subjects you need to teach. It's frustrating to deal with.

I genuinely wish this game existed without research. I should just be able to hire teachers with qualifications to teach subjects, or upgrade them with money to teach these subjects. Anything regarding advanced cleaning equipment or kitchen should just be more money. Student club should be something that you need to fulfill requirements for.

This game would be so much more thematically sensible without research.
I didn't enjoy my time with the game. Terrible UI

[h2] A fun SIM game that went the route of releasing on different consoles before finishing.[/h2]
[h3] Did have fun with it, but development has stopped, sadly.[/h3]

Had fun, but two dreadful things have seemed to happen:
- The lead artist had RL medical issues and was unable to continue.
- Management focused on releasing an unfinished game on multiple consoles.

[b]Artist leaving:[/b]  I hope they are well and its really unfortunate to hear.  I love the artstyle in game.  Maybe in the future they'll be able to return.

[b]Company focus on multi-platform:[/b]  Nope.  [u]Biggest sin of an indie game[/u].  Absolutely nope.

There are unfinished parts of the game:  
‚ùå Only one student interacts with the Student Counsel room.  
‚ùå There are only two clubs for Artist and Sports (Humanities and Science missing).  
‚ùå There is a noticeable lack of world maps to choose from.
‚ùå English translation isn't finished.  Specialist Teacher information boxes have badly translated terms that are ambiguous. 
‚ùå Doing athletic sports doesn't reduce character weight.  (you'll find out lmao)
‚ùå The schoolbell sound üîä is going to get REALLY annoying.
‚ùå There are two "Sound Effect" sliders in Settings, yet neither of those control the school bell independently.
‚ùå NPCs don't even use the Training Room.
‚ùå Cafeterias need seats for the total population, yet only ~4-8 people are in there at one time.
‚ùå Early-Mid game, your biggest money maker is selling candy.  The playground area receives little to no visitors.  The entire student body seems to entertain themselves with candy.  
‚ùå Guard station checkpoints are supposed to collect contraband and store in your inventory, but doesn't.
‚ùå Student Field trips all seem to be done by foot, despite students commuting via bicycle, bus, metro, cars...  Doesn't make sense that one cannot send a class somewhere by bus.
‚ùå When a field trip departs, the students are gone, but the teachers go to their schedule classrooms and teach.  Who is leaving with the kids???
‚ùå Sending teachers to Training doesn't remove them from the building.  This is actually helpful as scheduling Teachers to specific classes isn't easy.  Likely, you're more meant to have a pool of teachers available at all times to teach.

The game feels fun, but it fades after your first playthrough.  On your second run, you're going to feel like you're playing a continuation of the first.  I get a lot of vibes from SimTower from back in the day.  Which isn't a bad thing, the Let's School formula is fun, but needs another year of polishing to really shine.

The UI is not very intuitive, and the tutorial doesn't do a very good job of explaining things. After trying three times (twice in career, once in sandbox) the gameplay feels sluggish and repetitive. Maybe after you get past the first 2-3 weeks of classes it improves, but overall it just wasn't fun. Wish I hadn't played for more than two hours since my refund request was rejected based on playtime. Oh well, at least it was on sale so it wasn't a total waste of money.

Infuriating in how unpolished many game aspects are, how unclear many game aspects are, and how bugged it is. The writing's lousy, many interactions are frustrating, but overall the game's a decent sim game that'll appeal not only to fans of Two-Point Campus and similar games, but to most (civ, colony, tycoon, etc) simulation fans overall. ..if you're willing to expend the energy to deal with the fact that the dev clearly released the game in an "expect post-release updates" state, and never provided those. 

Ultimately, your appreciation of the game's going to boil down to your commitment to the genre- I'm going to continue playing the game, despite the annoyances having given me a literal headache, but I just can't recommend the game in general, since the frustrations and weak tutorial are going to run off those unfamiliar with, or less invested in the genre. 

Basically, the same reason I wouldn't recommend the original ascii-form Dwarf Fortress. It's a game a certain niche is going to appreciate, but the frustrations make it not for everyone. And, I mean, at least that game has the excuse of "this is an intentional design, since I want to focus on simulation development before graphic development", whereas Let's School.. well, let's just say it graduated a bit too early, and not with flying colors.
not that fun , thought it would be a bit more similar to the two point games based on the demo ,  glad i got this as part of a bundle. its Fine as a dull podcast game i guess

The game feels fun, but it fades after your first playthrough.  On your second run, you're going to feel like you're playing a continuation of the first.  I get a lot of vibes from SimTower from back in the day.  Which isn't a bad thing, the Let's School formula is fun, but needs another year of polishing to really shine.

The UI is not very intuitive, and the tutorial doesn't do a very good job of explaining things. After trying three times (twice in career, once in sandbox) the gameplay feels sluggish and repetitive. Maybe after you get past the first 2-3 weeks of classes it improves, but overall it just wasn't fun. Wish I hadn't played for more than two hours since my refund request was rejected based on playtime. Oh well, at least it was on sale so it wasn't a total waste of money.

Infuriating in how unpolished many game aspects are, how unclear many game aspects are, and how bugged it is. The writing's lousy, many interactions are frustrating, but overall the game's a decent sim game that'll appeal not only to fans of Two-Point Campus and similar games, but to most (civ, colony, tycoon, etc) simulation fans overall. ..if you're willing to expend the energy to deal with the fact that the dev clearly released the game in an "expect post-release updates" state, and never provided those. 

Ultimately, your appreciation of the game's going to boil down to your commitment to the genre- I'm going to continue playing the game, despite the annoyances having given me a literal headache, but I just can't recommend the game in general, since the frustrations and weak tutorial are going to run off those unfamiliar with, or less invested in the genre. 

Basically, the same reason I wouldn't recommend the original ascii-form Dwarf Fortress. It's a game a certain niche is going to appreciate, but the frustrations make it not for everyone. And, I mean, at least that game has the excuse of "this is an intentional design, since I want to focus on simulation development before graphic development", whereas Let's School.. well, let's just say it graduated a bit too early, and not with flying colors.
not that fun , thought it would be a bit more similar to the two point games based on the demo ,  glad i got this as part of a bundle. its Fine as a dull podcast game i guess

I received this as a gift and I have absolutely no idea how this game has this positive reviews.

Granted, I've only gotten 16 minutes into this game, but there's a reason for that:

- Both the English and German translations are clearly either unreviewed AI/machine translation or created without providing the translators with any context. The German version of "let's give back to the local community" is translated literally, ending up as the equivalent of "let us return items backwards toward the localised group". It's incomprehensible in most cases. UI translations are messed up and don't fit the context in which they are used. For example, the average employee satisfaction UI element is awkwardly called "Happiness of the employee". It's AI or cheap outsourcing nonsense.

- Text bleeds out of their respective areas and boxes constantly and UI clips into each other. The text of the "Save and quit" button in German ("Speichern und beenden") is double the length of the button that's supposed to hold it, cutting off on both sides.

- I think the game should disclose a little more clearly that it's specifically simulating a certain kind of Japanese schools. The entire structure of the game and its school system is based on Japan, which was a disappointment for me as I was looking for a relatively relatable school management tycoon game, and the idea of sex-segregation, school uniforms and such are alien and offputting to me.

- The art style and writing are so far generic and uninspired, it's very much the kind of dialogue you'd get in a free mobile game trying to make you buy ingame currency 'to speed up construction' or whatnot. You get utterly generic characters like "Brick the Construction Assistant" telling you how to use the demolition feature, while you can practically smell that "Buy 5 gems now or watch an ad to instantly complete demolition!" that thankfully never comes; it feels like no love or passion went into the game at all.

Either way, this looks and feels very, very much like a cheap, barely functional, janky mobile game rather than a fully-fledged PC management tycoon.

Worst of all (as mentioned) the translations ‚Äì for German especially ‚Äì are genuinely incomprehensible. Looking into the credits, they were made by some random Chinese company, with no actual translators or localisation QA folks credited by name. It's probably just AI. That's honestly the worst part. It's practically unplayable in German.

This game is really good, i really love it, until I realized that I couldn't get 4 achievements, namely population win, facility win, club victory and teaching win in one playthrough, it was very stupid, I had spent a lot of time to achieve all of that, and I only got one, I had to repeat it again to get 3 other achievements and had to use tricks to get the remaining 3 achievements. Why wasn't there a notice that each achievement could only be obtained in one playthrough, waste my time
The game is fantastic! However, if you expect new contents, do NOT download the game. It has been abandoned.
this had so much potential but there are so many bugs that developers refuse to fix, there hasn't been an update in over a year

I actually really like the game. Especially designing the school is a delight.

However, one aspect I feel is completely unnecessary and drags the game: Research.

You NEED to research because you will be required to teach advanced subjects that you need to research, and not just that, but to unlock things such as heating, cleaning, student club, etc. It's a drag on your economy as research requires you to hire staff dedicated to it. Also if you are behind, it basically bombs your game because you can't teach the subjects you need to teach. It's frustrating to deal with.

I genuinely wish this game existed without research. I should just be able to hire teachers with qualifications to teach subjects, or upgrade them with money to teach these subjects. Anything regarding advanced cleaning equipment or kitchen should just be more money. Student club should be something that you need to fulfill requirements for.

This game would be so much more thematically sensible without research.

So sad, this game could be really nice. It feels like a neat managemen simulation of a school. There is a big level of complexity, construction and management.

There are unfinished parts of the game:

‚ùå English translation isn't finished.  Specialist Teacher information boxes have badly translated terms that are ambiguous. 
‚ùå Doing athletic sports doesn't reduce character weight.  (you'll find out lmao)
‚ùå The schoolbell sound üîä is going to get REALLY annoying.
‚ùå There are two "Sound Effect" sliders in Settings, yet neither of those control the school bell independently.
‚ùå NPCs don't even use the Training Room.
‚ùå Cafeterias need seats for the total population, yet only ~4-8 people are in there at one time.
‚ùå Early-Mid game, your biggest money maker is selling candy.  The playground area receives little to no visitors.  The entire student body seems to entertain themselves with candy.  
‚ùå Guard station checkpoints are supposed to collect contraband and store in your inventory, but doesn't.
‚ùå Student Field trips all seem to be done by foot, despite students commuting via bicycle, bus, metro, cars...  Doesn't make sense that one cannot send a class somewhere by bus.
‚ùå When a field trip departs, the students are gone, but the teachers go to their schedule classrooms and teach.  Who is leaving with the kids???
‚ùå Sending teachers to Training doesn't remove them from the building.  This is actually helpful as scheduling Teachers to specific classes isn't easy.  Likely, you're more meant to have a pool of teachers available at all times to teach.

I actually really like the game. Especially designing the school is a delight.

However, one aspect I feel is completely unnecessary and drags the game: Research.

You NEED to research because you will be required to teach advanced subjects that you need to research, and not just that, but to unlock things such as heating, cleaning, student club, etc. It's a drag on your economy as research requires you to hire staff dedicated to it. Also if you are behind, it basically bombs your game because you can't teach the subjects you need to teach. It's frustrating to deal with.

I genuinely wish this game existed without research. I should just be able to hire teachers with qualifications to teach subjects, or upgrade them with money to teach these subjects. Anything regarding advanced cleaning equipment or kitchen should just be more money. Student club should be something that you need to fulfill requirements for.

This game would be so much more thematically sensible without research.

So sad, this game could be really nice. It feels like a neat managemen simulation of a school. There is a big level of complexity, construction and management.
However, the UI/UX is abyssimal. Most of the time you have no idea what influences what. Aside from that there are some terrible design choices. E.g. why is a class always linked to a room? I for one build in advance so I create a new classroom for the upcoming school year. However, that creates a new class that is shown as error (since there are no teachers or students in it). The next year then it gets promoted to grade 2 where as it was only meant for grade one by then.
This is just one of so many examples which makes the game cluttered and hard to understand. There are many values shown where you just don't have any idea where they are coming from nor what they do. Its basically learning by doing.

[h2] A fun SIM game that went the route of releasing on different consoles before finishing.[/h2]
[h3] Did have fun with it, but development has stopped, sadly.[/h3]

Had fun, but two dreadful things have seemed to happen:
- The lead artist had RL medical issues and was unable to continue.
- Management focused on releasing an unfinished game on multiple consoles.

[b]Artist leaving:[/b]  I hope they are well and its really unfortunate to hear.  I love the artstyle in game.  Maybe in the future they'll be able to return.

[b]Company focus on multi-platform:[/b]  Nope.  [u]Biggest sin of an indie game[/u].  Absolutely nope.

There are unfinished parts of the game:  
‚ùå Only one student interacts with the Student Counsel room.  
‚ùå There are only two clubs for Artist and Sports (Humanities and Science missing).  
‚ùå There is a noticeable lack of world maps to choose from.
‚ùå English translation isn't finished.  Specialist Teacher information boxes have badly translated terms that are ambiguous. 
‚ùå Doing athletic sports doesn't reduce character weight.  (you'll find out lmao)
‚ùå The schoolbell sound üîä is going to get REALLY annoying.
‚ùå There are two "Sound Effect" sliders in Settings, yet neither of those control the school bell independently.
‚ùå NPCs don't even use the Training Room.
‚ùå Cafeterias need seats for the total population, yet only ~4-8 people are in there at one time.
‚ùå Early-Mid game, your biggest money maker is selling candy.  The playground area receives little to no visitors.  The entire student body seems to entertain themselves with candy.  
‚ùå Guard station checkpoints are supposed to collect contraband and store in your inventory, but doesn't.
‚ùå Student Field trips all seem to be done by foot, despite students commuting via bicycle, bus, metro, cars...  Doesn't make sense that one cannot send a class somewhere by bus.
‚ùå When a field trip departs, the students are gone, but the teachers go to their schedule classrooms and teach.  Who is leaving with the kids???
‚ùå Sending teachers to Training doesn't remove them from the building.  This is actually helpful as scheduling Teachers to specific classes isn't easy.  Likely, you're more meant to have a pool of teachers available at all times to teach.

The game feels fun, but it fades after your first playthrough.  On your second run, you're going to feel like you're playing a continuation of the first.  I get a lot of vibes from SimTower from back in the day.  Which isn't a bad thing, the Let's School formula is fun, but needs another year of polishing to really shine.

The UI is not very intuitive, and the tutorial doesn't do a very good job of explaining things. After trying three times (twice in career, once in sandbox) the gameplay feels sluggish and repetitive. Maybe after you get past the first 2-3 weeks of classes it improves, but overall it just wasn't fun. Wish I hadn't played for more than two hours since my refund request was rejected based on playtime. Oh well, at least it was on sale so it wasn't a total waste of money.

Infuriating in how unpolished many game aspects are, how unclear many game aspects are, and how bugged it is. The writing's lousy, many interactions are frustrating, but overall the game's a decent sim game that'll appeal not only to fans of Two-Point Campus and similar games, but to most (civ, colony, tycoon, etc) simulation fans overall. ..if you're willing to expend the energy to deal with the fact that the dev clearly released the game in an "expect post-release updates" state, and never provided those. 

Ultimately, your appreciation of the game's going to boil down to your commitment to the genre- I'm going to continue playing the game, despite the annoyances having given me a literal headache, but I just can't recommend the game in general, since the frustrations and weak tutorial are going to run off those unfamiliar with, or less invested in the genre. 

Basically, the same reason I wouldn't recommend the original ascii-form Dwarf Fortress. It's a game a certain niche is going to appreciate, but the frustrations make it not for everyone. And, I mean, at least that game has the excuse of "this is an intentional design, since I want to focus on simulation development before graphic development", whereas Let's School.. well, let's just say it graduated a bit too early, and not with flying colors.
not that fun , thought it would be a bit more similar to the two point games based on the demo ,  glad i got this as part of a bundle. its Fine as a dull podcast game i guess

I received this as a gift and I have absolutely no idea how this game has this positive reviews.

Granted, I've only gotten 16 minutes into this game, but there's a reason for that:

- Both the English and German translations are clearly either unreviewed AI/machine translation or created without providing the translators with any context. The German version of "let's give back to the local community" is translated literally, ending up as the equivalent of "let us return items backwards toward the localised group". It's incomprehensible in most cases. UI translations are messed up and don't fit the context in which they are used. For example, the average employee satisfaction UI element is awkwardly called "Happiness of the employee". It's AI or cheap outsourcing nonsense.

- Text bleeds out of their respective areas and boxes constantly and UI clips into each other. The text of the "Save and quit" button in German ("Speichern und beenden") is double the length of the button that's supposed to hold it, cutting off on both sides.

- I think the game should disclose a little more clearly that it's specifically simulating a certain kind of Japanese schools. The entire structure of the game and its school system is based on Japan, which was a disappointment for me as I was looking for a relatively relatable school management tycoon game, and the idea of sex-segregation, school uniforms and such are alien and offputting to me.

- The art style and writing are so far generic and uninspired, it's very much the kind of dialogue you'd get in a free mobile game trying to make you buy ingame currency 'to speed up construction' or whatnot. You get utterly generic characters like "Brick the Construction Assistant" telling you how to use the demolition feature, while you can practically smell that "Buy 5 gems now or watch an ad to instantly complete demolition!" that thankfully never comes; it feels like no love or passion went into the game at all.

Either way, this looks and feels very, very much like a cheap, barely functional, janky mobile game rather than a fully-fledged PC management tycoon.

Worst of all (as mentioned) the translations ‚Äì for German especially ‚Äì are genuinely incomprehensible. Looking into the credits, they were made by some random Chinese company, with no actual translators or localisation QA folks credited by name. It's probably just AI. That's honestly the worst part. It's practically unplayable in German.

This game is really good, i really love it, until I realized that I couldn't get 4 achievements, namely population win, facility win, club victory and teaching win in one playthrough, it was very stupid, I had spent a lot of time to achieve all of that, and I only got one, I had to repeat it again to get 3 other achievements and had to use tricks to get the remaining 3 achievements. Why wasn't there a notice that each achievement could only be obtained in one playthrough, waste my time
The game is fantastic! However, if you expect new contents, do NOT download the game. It has been abandoned.
this had so much potential but there are so many bugs that developers refuse to fix, there hasn't been an update in over a year
